Let a x'' + b x' + cx = 0, where a \neq 0 and b^2 - 4ac = 0.
Show that x_1(t) = e^{-bt/2a} is a solution to a x'' + b x' + cx = 0.
Assume that y = v(t) x_1(t) = v(t) e^{-bt/2a} is a solution to a x'' + b x' + cx = 0 and show that v(t) = c_1 + c_2 t. Thus, x(t) = c_1 e^{-bt/2a} + c_2 t e^{-bt/2a} is a general solution for a x'' + b x' + cx = 0.

Consider the equation y'' - (2 \alpha -1) y' + \alpha (\alpha - 1) y =0. Determine all values of \alpha, if any, for which all solutions tend toward zero as t \to \infty. Also, determine the values of \alpha, if any, for which all nonzero solutions become unbounded as t \to \infty.

Reduction of Order. Suppose that x_1(t) is a solution (not identically zero) to the equation x'' + p(t) x' + q(t) x = 0.
Assume that x(t) = v(t) x_1(t) is a solution to x'' + p(t) x' + q(t) x = 0 and derive the equation x_1 v'' +(2x_1' + px_1)v' = 0.

Show that x_1(t) = 1/t is a solution to 2 t^2 x'' + 3t x' - x = 0 for t \gt 0 and find a second linearly independent solution to ().

Euler Equations. An important class of second-order linear differential equations are equations of the form t^2 y'' + \alpha t y' + \beta y = 0, where t \gt 0 and \alpha and \beta are real constants. An equation of this form is called an Euler equation.
Show that the substitution x = \ln t transforms an Euler equation into an equation of constant coefficients. {\em Hint}: Show that
\frac{dy}{dt} & = \frac{dx}{dt} \frac{dy}{dx} \frac{d^2y}{dt^2} & = \left( \frac{dx}{dt} \right)^2 \frac{d^2y}{dx^2} + \frac{d^2x}{dt^2} \frac{dy}{dx}.
Solve the equation t^2 y'' + 4ty' + 2y = 0.
